chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Vasectomy
chapter.summary: Covers the advantages, disadvantages, risks, and efficacy of vasectomy (male sterilization).
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years to 60 years (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should l assess a man considering a vasectomy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• See the section on How should I assess someone who is considering sterilization? in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.
  • In addition, the partner's suitability for sterilization should be assessed, as the couple's clinical history, present symptoms, and/or examination findings may influence which partner goes forward to have sterilization.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give to a man considering a vasectomy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Give advice and written information about:
    • The advantages, disadvantages, and risks of vasectomy. 
    • The efficacy of vasectomy.
    • Alternative long-term reversible methods of contraception and the relative efficacy of each method. See the section on comparative effectiveness of contraceptive methods in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.
    • The success rates associated with reversal, should this procedure be necessary. Advise that:
      • The NHS does not routinely offer reversal operations.
      • Reported success rates (the presence of motile sperm in a post-operative semen sample) of reversal operations vary from 40% to over 97%. 
      • The success rate reduces the longer the time interval from the vasectomy.
    • The need to use effective contraception until azoospermia has been confirmed by post-vasectomy semen analysis (PVSA).
      • The way in which azoospermia is confirmed depends on local protocols, but the optimal time to schedule a PVSA is 12 weeks after the procedure. 
      • In a small minority of men, non-motile sperm persist after vasectomy. In such cases, 'special clearance' to stop contraception may be given when fewer than 100,000 non-motile sperm/mL are found in a fresh specimen examined at least 7 months after vasectomy.
  • Reassure the man that vasectomy:
    • Does not increase the risk of impotence, testicular cancer or heart disease.
    • Has been associated with an increased risk of prostate cancer, but this link is unlikely to be causal.
  • Provide appropriate aftercare advice.
  • The Family Planning Association provides a useful leaflet with information on male sterilization [FPA, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Male and female sterilisation [FSRH, 2014].


Testicular cancer and vasectomy

  • There is a lack of evidence examining the association between vasectomy and  testicular cancer [FSRH, 2014].
    • The majority of case-control studies and cohort studies examining vasectomy and the risk of testicular cancer concluded that there is no evidence of an increased risk of testicular cancer.
    • Two studies concluded that there was evidence of a statistically significant increase in testicular cancer following vasectomy, however these studies were limited by a short follow-up period and possible ascertainment bias.

Heart disease and vasectomy

  • There is no evidence to support a link between heart disease and vasectomy [FSRH, 2014].
    • Three cohort studies and a case control study failed to find an association between vasectomy and cardiovascular disease.

Prostate cancer and vasectomy 

  • Case-control studies and cohort studies examining vasectomy and the risk of prostate cancer have produced conflicting results [FSRH, 2014].
    • The majority of studies have not found any association between vasectomy, age at vasectomy, time since vasectomy, and prostate cancer.
    • Two cohort studies, a meta-analysis, and a systematic review suggested a small but statistically significant increased risk of prostate cancer, however, this can be explained by bias or confounding factors.

subChapters.fullItemName: Advantages, disadvantages and risks of vasectomy
subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the advantages, disadvantages, and risks associated with vasectomy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Advantages

  • Very effective in preventing pregnancy.
  • Permanent.
  • Sex need not be interrupted to use contraception.

Disadvantages

  • It requires a minor surgical procedure that carries a small risk of haematoma and infection.
  • There is a post-operative period for vasectomy to be confirmed as effective.
    • Effective contraception is required until azoospermia is confirmed — 12 weeks is the optimal time to schedule a post-vasectomy semen analysis. 
  • People may regret having had the procedure:
    • The assessment process is designed to ensure that people at risk for regret are identified and fully informed about alternative long-acting reversible contraceptive methods.
  • Vasectomy cannot easily be reversed, and the NHS does not routinely offer reversal procedures.
  • Vasectomy does not protect against sexually transmitted infections.
  • Rarely, the procedure fails after clearance has been given that there are no spermatozoa in the ejaculate.
    • Late failure is defined as the presence of sperm after confirmation of sterility (azoospermia or special clearance at post vasectomy semen analysis [PVSA]). 
    • The rate of late failure due is reported to be between 0.03% and 1.2%.

Risks

  • There is a small risk of testicular or scrotal chronic post vasectomy pain (CPVP), which may develop months or years after the procedure. 
    • The incidence of CPVP ranges from 1-14%.
  • The risk of pain adversely affecting quality of life has not been well quantified by controlled trials.
  • An unpublished cohort study reported that 1 in 300 men previously asymptomatic, experienced pain which was severe enough to require medical attention and/or to affect quality of life [FSRH, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Male and female sterilisation [FSRH, 2014], and the Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada (SOGC) guideline Canadian contraception consensus. Part 2 [SOGC, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How effective is vasectomy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Vasectomy has a lifetime failure rate of approximately 1 in 2000 men following negative semen testing.

[FSRH, 2014]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What follow up and aftercare advice should I give a man who has had a vasectomy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise men who have had a vasectomy to: 
    • Seek medical help if they have any health concerns following the procedure, such as: 
      • Persistent bleeding.
      • Pain.
      • Infection.
      • Rapidly enlarging one-sided scrotal haematoma. 
    • Take a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for pain or discomfort following the procedure, unless contraindicated. See the CKS topic on NSAIDs - prescribing issues.
    • Rest and refrain from strenuous activity until pain permits.
    • Abstain from sexual activity for between 2 to 7 days.
    • Wear supportive underpants or athletic support for the first few days following the procedure to support the scrotum and reduce discomfort, including at night for the initial 48 hours, or longer according to symptoms.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Male and female sterilisation [FSRH, 2014] and an information leaflet published by the Family Planning Association, Your guide to male and female sterilisation [FPA, 2015].
